title: Clarify precedence with ^ in chained comparison

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-suggestion-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: suggestions generated by the compiler applied by cargo fix

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-papercut
labels.description: Diagnostic error that needs small tweaks

labels.name: D-invalid-suggestion
labels.description: A structured suggestion resulting in incorrect code

body:
```rust
fn foo(x: i32, y: i32, z: i32) -> bool {
    x < y ^ y < z // error: chained comparison operators require parentheses
}
```
Actual output:
```
error: chained comparison operators require parentheses
 --> src/lib.rs:2:7
  |
2 |     x < y ^ y < z
  |       ^^^^^^^^^^^
  |
  = help: use `::<...>` instead of `<...>` if you meant to specify type arguments
  = help: or use `(...)` if you meant to specify fn arguments

error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/lib.rs:2:17
  |
2 |     x < y ^ y < z
  |                 ^ expected bool, found i32

error: aborting due to 2 previous errors
```
It would be helpful to clarify that `^` has a higher precedence than `<` and suggest that the user parenthesises `(x < y) ^ (y < z)`, which would result in the correct expected type.
